bGFg0skurryb-LxtvlUA1w.text: Good food and good service. Ask for downstairs table and make sure to reserve a table cos it's always fully booked.

5tXh1D00aQXpHYGFGH_Jcg.text: My sisters and I were staying at St. Martins and stumbled on Le Garrick quite by chance ...what a great find! We were seated in the basement, it was a Little bit dark at first, but in a few minutes you get 'adjusted' to your surroundings. I got the Moules Marinieres which was very good. Older sis got the Calamari in spicy sauce, the portion was small, the flavor anything but small! Younger sis got the Merguez sausages which were phenomenal! Absolutely loved the food and the service.

photos.caption: Photo of Le Garrick - London, United Kingdom. "Cassolette" de calamari au piment rouge
Photo of Le Garrick - London, United Kingdom. Moules Marinieres
Photo of Le Garrick - London, United Kingdom. Baby merguez sausages

dR19-Fy6hZnkPFjm0nqZUg.text: Great little place, almost always a free table in spite of Covent Garden location. The absinthe is pretty decent too.

C39md26omixGs9vNGR5FjA.text: A delightful evening...french onion soup, calamari, bread, mussels, risotto. Even better was the service and ambience. Marion was a delight, our table was perfect and they even had a birthday message waiting for my daughter at the table.

qANjHotuYTB7xeal5AO1mQ.text: I liked this restaurant. The decor is really nice and intimate, the food was good and the menu was varied without being too extensive. My friends and I had a really nice time here.So why the lost stars? Well, for one thing, there was a plague of flies buzzing around us the whole time. I for one had showered earlier in the day, so after a couple of sly whiffs of my being, I ascertained that it wasn't us that brought the flies in. We asked the waitress and she said that there had been an infestation that they were dealing with.Now, I don't know the rules on restaurant hygiene, but in my humble opinion, if a restaurant has an infestation of flies to the point where it's actually pestering customers, it should not be open. It was disgusting having all these little critters buzzing around our food and drink for the entirety of the meal.Also, I wasn't too keen on our waitress. She was nice enough, but she seemed to adopt the mannerisms of the flies; she kept buzzing over every couple of minutes to look at our plates to see if  she could take them. I actually got really annoyed when she did this when 1 of the 3 of us was clearly still eating, even though the other two had finished. I don't know if she was in a rush to get us out or something, but being constantly interrupted by her was pretty irritating.

IfHO2nMIEVS4QIrrcavqUg.text: I had just finished my dinner there and her is my review:Basement atmosphere: 5/5Service : 5/5Food: 2/5The atmosephere downstairs is really intimate and out of the  ordinary. The service was nice and the staff was friendly untill  I paid the bill. The main dishes were way below expectation mainly because the meat was hard and dry. Also, the bill comes with a hand written "optional" 12.5% service charge and I was sort of challenged for leaving less than that! That is the first time for me! I think I would have given a five rating and paid full gratuity if the food was excellent.

Wu3YhLyjeXSsXKgk2PU6yg.text: I was immediately heartened by the upbeat and very friendly French hostess and waitress that attended to us.  That was tempered when we were brought downstairs, as basement rooms in london restaurants can be stiffling and dank.  But not here!  Although certainly tight, it's a comforting catacomb of warmth and character, with arches and lanterns everywhere making cozy hideaways for group tables and a live musician who expertly played the blues on the mike.The food was a very fair price for really nice French bistro food.. we had a range of what was on offer and it was all a cut above.  The bubbly waitress brought bottles of a wonderfully peppery syrah, and kept pace with our slight obnoxiousness, and we bounced out of there full of good food and wine and spirit.

lq4pnUm3ihT6GUYmkA7BHg.text: Loved this place until we saw mice running around under the chairs. I don't buy the idea that this is a fact of life in central London. There's plenty of good restaurants nearby that are clean and free of mice in open sight.If you do go, have the beef bourguignon. One of the best I've had outside France.

pzwY-2lWBy27UHOifs4LuQ.text: Le Garrick is a great little french bistro that came highly recommended by one of my friends, he has been eating here for over 10 years. It certainly had a real charm and the food was delicious. The restaurant is spread over two floors, we sat downstairs where it was cosy and a bit higaldypicaldy with mismatch wooden chairs and tables. You might need to be careful on the stairs on the way out especially if you enjoy the excellent French wines available here.  You will find yourself sitting pretty close to your neighbouring diners but it's still quite intimate and very romantic if you are eating as a couple. During our meal a young singer performed, it was very atmospheric and added to the evening. The staff were young and French, and respected our attempts to pick traditional french dishes and regional wines. The food was honest traditional and delicious, we were too full to eat desert but finished with nice coffee. It's very easy to spend the whole evening here

t3EKMaayS8_bYavVqvArBg.text: I love this place. - First, for the building itself: intimate, full of history (1860's), an interior with alcoves, stone walls, corners & small areas,... - Second, for the food which is really good & tasty. Service is also great and the staff very friendly. You feel really well looked after all the way. A wide range of wine to choose from and some good recommendations from the staff. Would highly recommend it for a romantic dinner. This is not an expensive restaurant for some good quality french cuisine.

nqt_Vv4X4Z3F3MpstpWEYg.text: The key word here is limited.  Small and quite upstairs with a maze of rooms and tables below. Small bar (for 4-5) as you descend the stairs then tight quarters. Packed with happy people so that's a good sign. I was seated at a two top in the hallway, constantly being bumped by servers and guests. Luckily there are only 4 tables in the hall and they are all for parties of 2. Best bet, bring 2 friends.  The wine list is small along with the menu. A prix fixe holiday 3 course was available but I stuck with the roots of this intriguing dungeon.I chose the only Pinot Noir and started with the French onion soup. When in Rome... Nothing extraordinary but not bad.The Sea bass was on the dry side so I added a pat of butter from the loaf basked passed on to add a bit of fun. It worked. The fish was server over creamed peas. How far can you take world peace/whirled peas?When offered dessert, I asked for a suggestion and "I would defiantly go with the lemon tart" flowed without hesitation. So be it. I must admit, I'm no fan of lemon flavored deserts but if this is what she wants me to eat. I'll oblige. The tart came out fast and was beautiful.If you paid attention, the theme here is limited. Limited spaceLimited wineLimited menuLimited flavourBut most of all...and most important here friends, limited price!The price combined with quick, friendly service of good, but not great food, gives Le Garrick a higher mark on my list from a 3 to a 4.Pop in before a show or just because you want a square meal for a good price. Le Garrick delivers. Young and fun all around.

ZDzxXSqxd_KqglnN_q-31w.text: While waiting for B and the lovely Ms Mapp to arrive at Le Garrick for dinner on Wednesday evening it dawned on me that I had been frequenting this French bistro for over 10 years. While not my favourite restaurant in town by any means it has a real charm and can be relied on to serve up classic French comfort food time after time. As Winter begins to draw in it's a great place for a mid-week supper and a good gossip with friends. Like football it's a game of two halves and the restaurant is spread over two floors; upstairs there are four or five tables with a good view through the large windows of the evening crowds heading up to Covent Garden or Leicester Square. It's a good spot to watch the world go by but my personal choice is the windowless basement with its labyrinth of small rooms furnished with an eclectic selection of wooden tables and chairs. You will find yourself sitting pretty close to. your neighbouring diners but it's still quite intimate and very romantic if you are eating as a couple. Its a popular choice with tourists, locals and those seeking a discreet venue for an illicit liaison so I would advise booking in advance.  There is also small bar downstairs which seats four at a squeeze if all the tables are taken. This Wednesday evening we had the pleasure of being entertained by a young "Sinatra" and accompanying pianist at the far end of the room. All very atmospheric and at just the right volume. Staff are mainly youngish French girls who bustle about with skill and dexterity - smile and treat them well and they will return the favour in spades!!  So once the ladies had finally arrived it was down to business with a bottle of the fine and a reasonably priced house white from a short but well edited list of French wine.  We kicked off by sharing the cheese fondue, camembert baked in its box with the addition of some wine and garlic. It's always good and although it's listed as a dish for two it will easily feed three. Some bread and little merguez sausages with onions on the side made this a very tasty start to our supper. After having had the fillet steak the weekend before at Gaucho I thought I would give the Onglet steak here, at a third of the price, a run out. The ladies agreed with me so it was three medium rare steaks with frites and béarnaise sauce on the side. Known as the "butchers" steak this comes really well tenderised, cooked to perfection and is full of robust meaty flavour. It's not going to win any awards for culinary innovation but it's good, honest food and pretty damm tasty. It's very easy to find the evening has slipped through your fingers at Le Garrick and before I knew it there was barely time for a creme brûlée, from the small selection of dessert classics, followed by an espresso and a dash to Charing Cross station to get the last train back to Nunhead. For regular London diners it's worth noting that you can make this a very cheap mid-week treat if you have invested in a "Taste London" card, which can be had for an annual fee of around £40, as you will get two for the price of one deal on the food. However, even without the discount you can bag yourself a bargain from the limited pre-theatre menu and I would say that it's well worth a visit if you find yourself in Covent Garden area in need of a good feed.

Z9zONlzUNM-gVrV9PylhRA.text: We went here for a last-minute bite on a Friday night and were quite pleased with what we got. It's pretty reasonably priced, and the service is pleasant. Most of the menu was pretty standard French brasserie stuff, but that was ok with us.

DSYVV_2CRI4Y2pCSsKeaAA.text: Good food and very lovely and caring service. Simple and enjoyable. Low noise levels for the area. Very convenient for a pre-theatre dinner. I recommend it.

r4dX5wcuHX2kcbjiXcttZw.text: I was not greatly impressed by this small and rather pokey restaurant. I get the feeling that it did not live up to its pretentions. The food was OK but simple. The service was very slow and not very attentive. The decor is quite pleasant but it is an awkward triangular site and I certainly would not want to eat outside on a busy pavement at lunch-time. At the charges, I'd expect a serving of at least one vegetable with each dish but there were none included. I think better value and service could be obtained elsewhere.

LiVq2XWb7d5bWCW-Ucvn0Q.text: Good spot in Covent Garden close to Theatreland. Pre theatre fixed price menu is limited but excellent value. Cosy atmosphere and efficient friendly service.

j7hyWwzgek3yglYyHhAwag.text: Le Garrick is a relatively cavernous restaurant. It serves a very meat biased menu, but the food is fantastic and the decor is very romantic. This would be an excellent restaurant for a first date. The tables are placed incredibly close together and the staff oscillate between attentive and comatosed. This is one of the nicest restaurants that I have been to in a long time, the food is excellent and the wine is also very tasty. Highly recommended.

-l20L8Uf65BpXdy0fcxfIg.text: really good surprise. I found this place by chance while looking for a place to dine with friends while enjoying the last bit of sun on this busy area. the service is very good wih super friendly staff and yummy food. this place really gives the feeling of being in a bistrot in Paris

ZW8-yDvVh1mwsXM3U2kplw.text: Unpretentious little gem that serves decent French food without fuss in the heart of theatreland. It might be easier to write a list of things the Gartick isn't: not posh, not a chain, not swanky, not expensive (assuming you can afford a theatre ticket), not full of drunk hedge fund managers. But that would do it a disservice. Le Garrick is really pleasant find, serving perfectly decent French food in the friendly but still slightly aloof manner that the French seem to have mastered.The salads are simple, the Onglet steak very nice with skinny French fries (of course). Not foodie fare, but very good.If you're looking for a nice place to grab a bite sitting down, where you can hear your friends, and not have to worry that a whopping bill is going to land at the end, go here. Recommend.

QB4gKhUqXP8iLirWmRnjiA.text: Such a lovely French restaurant situated in Covent Garden (Leicester Square closest station). You feel like you're in the extension of the owners' living room! Gorgeous, hearty dishes like the boeuf bourguignon and steak frites (I've been more than once!) and amazing starters. You must try the calamari - such distinct flavouring! This has become one of my favourite restaurants.

vSN8OTdtFrFtNXOzIxR7gA.text: Very pleasant and cosy French restaurant serving perfectly acceptable food at reasonable prices. Service is friendly and brisk and, crucially, you don't have to stand around for forty minutes before you eat, because they take reservations.

Q3CV5dRbtuwiSxPQsdGkdw.text: * Amazing food, check.* Amazing service, check.* Amazing night, check. First things first: make reservations, preferably with a group of 6 - 8 and ask for one of the lovely 'booths' downstairs. Second, order wine, tap water (yes, extra star for service) and look at the menu. You notice that it's French Classics? You've noticed well! Beautiful Foie Gras, Moules Marinieres, succulent duck confit, baby chicken and the list goes on and on and on.I must say, I was very impressed that 1) the service was quick and friendly, 2) the food came quite quickly, and 3) cooked to perfection. Let me explain why: we were with a large group ( 9 people), we came in at peak hour (8 PM) on a very busy Friday night. Located in Covent Garden, you'd expect lots of tourists and stunning prices. Nope, not here. Good food and not too expensive, even for London standards. Tip: apparently, they also do live music....

6JF1-3IDKeJykdS-d-QGow.text: Happy staff, high-quality French food and a lovely restaurant with a great underground section (looks infinitely more cosy than the upstairs seating area).This place isn't for super fat people as the tables and chairs are teeny weeny - we had to squeeze in next to a drunk group of four women for our romantic meal for two, and it was quite hard to hear anything other than their cackling away.I think as long as you strike lucky with your table (maybe ask for on the tables further away from other diners) this place could easily hit 5*.

UU9CMY7W92HD0SMkgxPd0A.text: Welcome to London my parents! To celebrate them being here, we decided to go see a show, very traditional middle class way of entertaining parents isn't it? Of course the problem with this is you have to find somewhere early to eat that serves quickly enough. Now I know what you're thinking, why not have something to eat after the show? Ingenious, but then of course that assumes that my mum isn't complaining about how her feet hurt and she's tired. So, thinking ahead, I booked a nice looking French restaurant in covent garden near to the theatre. Mum is of course picky and now on (another) diet so I thought French would suit this quite well - not too heavy and she can feel continental, fulfilling more middle class desires of hers. So along we went to Le Garrick. First impressions were nice location and good decor; Very shabby chic, iron staircase going into the basement where there were carefully placed tables in really interesting nooks and crannies. Of course they did that annoying thing of trying to squeeze in one too many tables so that everyone felt a bit awkward when moving their chair to go to the loo. You move back your chair carefully so you don't make that scraping sound on the floor and you accidentally hit the table behind you sending soup everywhere. Thankfully that didn't happen to me.. This time!!Typical prices, ranging from 12 - 18 quid. I had duck in orange sauce with wilted greens, which was a bit sweet and had rind in the sauce, not great. But the duck was nicely cooked so some points there. Dad had beef bourguignon which looked nice, although it probably should have been served in a deeper bowl. Mum had grilled lamb shank and ratatouille, which in her middle class way was described as distinctly average.All in all an average meal, nice service and good place. But around Covent Garden, there's better out there.

photos.caption: Photo of Le Garrick - London, United Kingdom. Rustic decor

_yhG9hpSLDcCXCWyWcmy4A.text: The fondue is a must-try. An authentic French brasserie, just as I like it. Reminds me of my darling Paris! :)

photos.caption: Photo of Le Garrick - London, United Kingdom

BljNArVM1i3EvWDeGAMduQ.text: Very nice ambiance, great service and delicious food. A gastronomic trifecta!  There were 4 of us and we decided we wanted to do a tasting menu but they didn't have one so we created our own! We had the mussels, onion soup and fois gras (to die for!). Then we had the 24 ounce rib eye with frites, the duck confit (my favorite of the night) and the special of the day - chicken in a creamy thyme sauce.  We shared two desserts - the chocolate mousse and lemon tarte. We had a nice bottle of French Pinot Noir, soft drinks and coffee. Total bill including tax and service was 135 pounds.  I would have given 5 stars if they had a tasting menu!

Mh90hy_wrR8DLa4iRPEyzQ.text: Great staff, great food! Went here for my cousins birthday celebration (nice quiet dinner somewhere we've never been before). I stumbled upon Le Garrick on the internet and the place itself beat my expectation with it's intimate setting (love the underground area!) and friendly staff. As this was a year ago, I don't remember what I had but the duck come to mind! Whatever it is , I know it tasted good as I recommended the restaurant to friends straight away. With it being in London, do expect a higher price for what you order. It came out to be about £25-30 a head which for good food and a special occasion can be compromised , still not bad. Book first though!

2d4_4w8ihtOiUSPMZnX7PQ.text: Fantastic food, friendly staff and an amazing location (make sure you ask to sit downstairs, which is an old converted cellar).Le Garrick fries are the best in London IMHO!

V2Prl5SMAUzvuBiE7-IWBQ.text: We went for a post theatre 2 course menu at around 10.30. The service was okay but at that time of the night we almost got double charged when I didn't complain. The mussels were really tasty though and the portion is very generous. I found it the setting a bit too dim for my taste though.

-a2mXK1Zg03y6YSisM3lxg.text: This is an adorable little (3.5 star) French restaurant on Garrick Street.  It is not white tablecloth, and not as expensive as other similar French restaurants.  The ambience is great, the service is friendly, and the food is lovely.  The bread with the French butter was a great way to start the meal.  We ordered the foie gras as our appetizer which was, of course, amazing.  Until this point, I think this place would have definitely received a 4 star review.  However, the salmon that I ordered as my main course left much to be desired.  I also tried a bite of the moules marinières (mussels), which were great!Other than the salmon, it was a great dining experience and I would recommend it as a solid place to eat if you are in the area.

jWxEsA6KNLFZD6nfD6BjNA.text: This restaurant represents the 4 Star and '££' category very well.   i.e it punches above its weight.i went a few years back and sat downstairs in their cellar style dining room complete with all the nooks and crannies, its a beautiful cosy restaurant.  This time we sat  upstairs in the smaller dining room to catch the last of the days sunshine.My wife has the Boeuf Bourguignon and i had the Duck a l'Orange.  The Bourguignon was excellent.  The Duck a l'Orange was good but it wasn't to my palates taste.  i asked the waiter to suggest a more savory style suggestion but she was quite convincing that she liked this duck better.  anyway next time will  get the duck confit!

lmniePK6F664rwokSIUpUA.text: I had the moules et frites, and it was delicious! Sometimes the moules marinieres white wine sauce can be too heavy, but this one was perfect. My friend had the coq au vin which was a special that day, and that too was very good. We had the day's cocktails which were very refreshing. From the outside, the restaurant looks a bit like a cheesy French tourist trap but there's a huge space downstairs which has more of a pub-like atmosphere (but refined)  -- hence the 'brasserie' in their name. I enjoyed my experience, except for the VERY annoying loud drunk american girls sitting at the next table who were flirting with the French waiter. But hopefully they won't be there next time :D

iBgX0E5xqux-NyZNQsDxSg.text: Came here for (American) Thanksgiving dinner, and was not disappointed. The ambiance is warm and inviting. The service was excellent. Food was fantastic. Worth the splurge!

X-5oEvgMSgJBVgdKyx3A2Q.text: wonderful find - Garrick is a legit (run by real french people), affordable brasserie with superb ambiance and excellent service. Took my in-laws there for a family dinner and sat downstairs in one of the little alcoves they have that gives the place such an intimate feel. perfect place for a group - plus they take reservations. food was solid - not superlative, but a great value for the money. particularly enjoyed the calamar cassoulet appetizer, the actual cassoulet dinner and the escargots.

IfhYpGK0u2TQCB7ujVY29g.text: What a fantastic restaurant this is. We lived down the street for two years, and this was our go to restaurant in London. It truly transports you...walking down the stairs and straight into Paris. Incredible atmosphere, wonderful food and excellent service. Cannot wait for our trip back to London to go back to Le Garrick!

SYT4nPbeyJbsgZMGh3I-CQ.text: We went in a group for a Friday night dinner, not only did we have our own private corner after reserving an area but the ambience and noise level were perfect. The food was good, the cheese fondue as an entree was delicious. Servers were attentive without being overcrowding!

rVn2r4Nlg64XFrolv-BDaw.text: On a corner in clear shot of Leicester station is a quaint French brasserie with lovely food inside. This is the duck confit you are looking for!Didn't see much to the upstairs but had a reserved table downstairs in very tight quarters. it very much is like a maze of tables, people and thin paths between them all. Cozy would be a nice word for it. Good wine, good company and good food. We started off with the mussels in white wine which I pretty much devoured, and my other half had the onion soup which for once i didn't despise. I'm not a fan of the soup, but this one was decent to me. For our main I ordered a salad, frittes, the Canard l'orange with mashed potatoes and spinach. The frigates were great, the salad tasted like plastic. I swear the dressing was made with melted plastic. It was pretty gross and they kindly took it off the bill. The duck i had was a bit over cooked but the flavours were still good so I wasn't too bothered by it. My other half ordered the duck confit on beans which was delicious and cooked to perfection. We topped off the meal with the Chocolate fondant (what I call a Lava cake) with ice cream dessert which was just heavenly. Prices were good, staff was great, food was decent. I'll definitely go again.

y3FWeE2LiWjAX12w7p7i5w.text: I came here for dinner after taking my mum shopping nearby. My mum's really hard to please so I had my fingers crossed because Le Garrick has been around forever and it reminds me of my favourite bistro in Paris.We ordered a salmon fillet with ratatouille, and a duck confit with minted beans. Both were delicious. Cooked perfectly, with just a little bit of twist to make it magical. Wine pairings were great. Our waiter was really friendly and patient with us. We were both grateful to have had such a wonderful meal after walking around central all afternoon on a hot summer's day. The dessert menu looked great too but we opted to go across the street to get gelato instead.I'd be happy to go back next time I'm need of dinner in the area.

-tjGdiHzg_oGKKepYoAxgQ.text: The duck was magnificent.  The French Fries were too.  My wife had mussels which she said were very good.  Somewhat small portions, at least for the duck.  But overall the food was great.  The wait staff was friendly and efficient. Great experience.

photos.caption: Photo of Le Garrick - London, United Kingdom

3l5uckbSzEfUU3gTNkDZ-Q.text: Lovely unimposing French restaurant located in Covent Garden. Romantic, dimly-lit, cozy ambiance...  great service... charming French accent...  super delicious boeuf bourguignon with a perfectly matching delicate Malbec... perfectly flaky whole bass... all so satisfying that life might seem like one light French evening out.

lYRVS_vXnuxs1Qq75Lfusg.text: We came here pre-theater with plenty of time to spare but we were seated on the street level which is not as intimate as the lower level nor as large.  While others have noted the décor is nice and old-fashioned, the upstairs gave you the feeling of not being near anything except the hustle and bustle of the street.  The waiters were French and spoke perfect English with their French accents, and the service was just fine, they were quite friendly too.The food was rather uninspiring.  The French onion soup was a dish any self-respecting French chef would have been embarrassed to serve.  The gruyere cheese was not so much melted on top under a broiler as it was simply dumped into the soup.  A couple of unmelted pieces that had fallen to the plate underneath the bowl (it was coarsely grated) tasted like they had been sitting in the refrigerator too long and had blended with smelly old food.  The cheese itself lacked flavor.  The crusty bread on top had also fallen into the soup.  The soup broth was fair, and the onions inside were fine.The steak frites was also just fair.  The steak had suffered from a bit of the fat flaming back up into it, which gives you that greasy burnt gasoline taste.  The frites were very skinny and decently cooked but unsalted.  Weird.  So I salted them.I did not taste the beef bourgignon but judging from Yelpers pictures, it looks like the sauce is a bit light and runny.  Unfortunately this was the only French restaurant near our theater.  Ah well, it filled us up.

swzeqr80OpYXnazGXph8LQ.text: Short Review:Yes. Yes. Yes. Get your arses in here quickly! One of the best authentic French restaurants I've been to. Every member of the staff, including the chef, is French. Food is not too rich, wide selection of wines, great ambiance, and very friendly and attentive staff. Highly recommend. Long Review:Thank God they have a 4-seat bar downstairs! Otherwise, my walk-in during the dinner hour would not have been accepted. They were, of course, completely booked. Nestled in the middle of Covent Garden, this cute unapologetically French goldmine was absolutely amazing - from the service, to the wine, to the food, to the ambience. High recommend!

dhCQE8iHvQmJNzKsoPl6lA.text: And ideal date night setting with candlelit ambiance. Food was generally good, but I was not expecting my duck breast to be overcooked at an above average rated French bistro. Our waiter was a disaster ..think we would have been better off without his service. Hope it's not a reflection of the rest of the staff. Manager was accommodating and checked in on us when he noticed something was off. 3.5 stars upgraded to a 4 considering ambiance and general nature of food.  Also, for having more than one duck choice on the menu compared to others!

pDD8VSDU-e-hlzY5iF_Qog.text: Great experience. First off the staff is awesome. Everyone from the bartenders to the servers really did a great job. We sat downstairs in one of the coves and it was very cool. It is a little tight in there but still cool.The food was all very good. I ordered the steak. The french fries were especially good. The wine was also spot on but it is expected at a french place.Definitely a cool place. I would recommend

p7AQ_8au_GttIyYkTEivqQ.text: Really enjoyed this place. The staff were friendly and our waitress was fun. Started with the foie gras which was very good and then the rib eye with the fries. Everything tasted great and was well prepared.  We really wanted to stay for dessert but had to rush off for another booking. If I lived here I would definitely frequent this place.  It had a quaint neighborhood vibe even though it's right around all the theatres.

ALuZQoeFQJ8ZsSrfXrE4oA.text: I came here with my mother for a nice break from your traditional British cuisine. I have the beef bourgogne and it was great! I wish they didn't have "packets" of butter though...just seems a little lazy to me and not befitting of the rustic French restaurant that it is.

arhYxfa2ym-HRpW8w-7Gvw.text: Jerson is a new and welcoming server who made sure to check on us whenever was necessary while also being able to create good conversation with our table. The food was delicious as well. We ordered the goat cheese salad, steak, lamb confit, etc.. everything was perfect! We definitely recommend this restaurant to everyone.

Gp5HN6gB4Freaz2FP3b5YA.text: What a cute little French restaurant! Great atmosphere, decor, and really nice and attentive staff. My husband had boeuf bourguignon and I had moules frites with a side salad. The mussels really hit the spot for me. I ate the whole thing with gusto. The fries are just there and don't add much to the dish in my opinion, but my husband ate them up, so overall we were happy with our food.

kCpPT8kw1B-3WlWEZcPxFQ.text: They charged us 5 pounds for two small baskets of bread without informing us that bread was an extra cost (plus bread was not very good esp if you have ever been to France. Too fluffy.) Very un-French. Beef Bourgogne was tasty though and moules marinieres had nice sauce even if slightly overcooked. Good service. Do not recommend though given how much great food there is in the rest of London!

DJEslUEnaNaNvgFv9D7FVA.text: Candle-lit restaurants with that old-fashioned smoky, sexy kind of charm have always appealed to me. They beckon and entice me in. I relax more in a restaurant that doesn't have glary lights; I feel myself kicking back and genuinely glowing, in the glow of it all!Le Garrick is one of those. Been there forever, and forever I have heard it calling to me, but never slowed down long enough to listen. Until recently that is, when my friend and I were in Covent Garden, craving somewhere charming, cosy and French. 'Oh, that'll be Le Garrick', and off we went.It's lovely, in that old fashioned, unpretentious lovely French kinda way. The staff are fun, sexy and, FRENCH (sexy by default then really) and they bob about happily, taking it all in their stride.The décor, effortlessly stylish, is rustic and pleasantly unrefined - wooden floors and chairs, exposed brick and boudoir wallpaper. The candle light hides any imperfections, for which I am grateful too.The food is as you'd expect from a French Brasserie - no surprises, just all the old staples, the epitome of French cooking. We tucked in to Coquilles St Jacques - seared scallops which were perfectly cooked, bouncy and succulent - and Cassolette de calamar à la plancha au piment d'espelette - calamari in the most exquisite, intensely rich, decadent, sweet buttery sauce with ginger, coriander and chilli. I have no words to really do this sauce justice, only to say that, had I been at home I would have undoubtedly licked the bowl clean. Subsequently, I ate far too much French bread, mopping up every last drop. Rib-eye and frites, an old brasserie dependable, was as good as any; and beef Bourguignon was unctuous and plentiful with another sauce to blow your mind. Aromatic, more'ish and deeply satisfying - another bowl-licker!Meanwhile, we enjoyed a rather quaffable 2007 Gevrey Chambertin, mindful not to quaff too quickly. And as the candles flickered, and the place gently hummed with mellifluous background noise, for just a moment I imagined I was in my favourite city in the world - Paris, in a 1940's foxy full skirted dress, with my French lover, Benoît, smoking and drinking Vermouth. I blink and it's gone. But what a lovely evening it has been, avec mon amis, Jeremy.

photos.caption: Photo of Le Garrick - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Le Garrick - London, United Kingdom. Calamari in an UMFORGETTABLE sauce
Photo of Le Garrick - London, United Kingdom. Beef Bourgignon

_tg5AtcEZWeuQNLUgw3oOw.text: The service here is good and everyone is very nice. Their calamari appetizer is one of the best calamari I've ever had. The calamari is tender and the sauce is addicting. You have to ask for more bread to dip the sauce. The snack rilettes is good. I like the tiny pickles on the top. They have frog legs as appetizer too. It tastes good and tender. The duck breast in orange sauce is interesting. The meat is ok tender though. Their recommendations on wine is really good too. Even though the seating is a bit tiny, the whole experience is awesome.

photos.caption: Photo of Le Garrick - London, United Kingdom. Mussels
Photo of Le Garrick - London, United Kingdom. Duck breast in orange sauce
Photo of Le Garrick - London, United Kingdom. Frog legs

wzZwP6ugtaYiy48taBge7Q.text: This sweet little restaurant is actually a real gem. We were sat downstairs which is very snug but in a cosy homely way! They've got the mood just right with candlelit tables and old fashioned decor and the menu has a great selection. We shared the fondue to start and I have duck in orange sauce for my main both of which were exquisite and my creme brûlée dessert was the best I've had in a while! The staff looked after us really well and were all lovely, and the complimentary shot at the end of the meal really did remind me of being in France! Recommend.

photos.caption: Photo of Le Garrick - London, United Kingdom. Creme brulee
Photo of Le Garrick - London, United Kingdom. Duck with orange sauce
Photo of Le Garrick - London, United Kingdom. Cheese fondue

WVO5TvJ47OeW1ufg16FFrw.text: Don't let the teeny tiny ground floor fool you - the basement is much larger and has alot of tables squished in, giving it a very intimate feel. The service was really great; we had great attention and very prompt, in keeping with our pre-theatre schedule. The food was really nice and the husband said his mussels were probably some of the best he's ever had.It's a great place for a pre-theatre dinner.

j8bg7YWBB1gA3MNwPg8UhA.text: Beautiful little brasserie serving French bistro fare in a quaintly setting. Big windows, amber lighting (good for dates), and joyful, friendly staff. They offer your standard bisfro fare of various steaks-- onglette, entrecot-- a fish of the day, mussels, and surprisingly, vegetarian dishes outside of the usual dreary mushroom risotto (£9.95). On my most recent visit I sampled the quinoa and roasted vegetable dish which was excellent. Fresh and full of flavour, it wasn't just some lame runner-up to the rest of the menu as is frequently the case in French places. Pricing is moderate, with most mains costing in the mid-teens range and wines between £21 - 48. Upstairs the seating is a bit cosy but fine.....the real highlight is downstairs. Creep down the spiral staircase and encounter what feels like a speakeasy: low, vaulted ceilings, tables for 4 or 6 people each ensconced in their own little area. Overall a nice choice for a chilled dinner experience.

wZE8dPGCJOAnBOsR3OSQYw.text: Quite simply the friendliest welcome I've had in years. Wonderful, romantic setting downstairs, great authentic French fare and lovely, lovely service. We had a great time and stayed more than 4 hours. We recommend the Merlot, the entrecôte and the boeuf bourgignon. Fantastique!!

X-U0Ic4OGcIzk1Ei2O-7TQ.text: Marion, such a lovely host who greeted us at the door before we even entered and made our dinner experience more homely and friendly than we could have imagined it to be. In the hustle and bustle of Covent Garden it's hard to believe that a gem like this exist- a beautiful French restaurant with 30 years of history. We were seated upstairs which itself was beautiful, dark and romantic, containing less than 10 tables which made it very cosy to be in. But when we return we must remember to request for a seat downstairs as it was another world down there, discovering it as I was making my way down the rustic metal spiral staircase to the toilets. It was like a barrel cellar area, low ceiling with little booth for diners to sit in with a bit more privacy. It was extremely romantic.I like a host that is decisive and confidence enough to suggest us wines when we asked for her choice and that was exactly what Marion did. We left it to her and I can honestly say for me who doesn't usually like wine, she made a very good choice, fruity full-bodied red wine that had a nice smooth aftertaste. It was a great pairing with my Cassoulet De Toulouse hence why she chose it.But before we started our mains we both shared a cheese fondue cooked with white wine and herbs - for two to share. It was incredible, runny, smooth and creamy full of flavour with the added wine and herbs. Although my favourite part had to be the harden bits around the edge that was stringy and slightly elastic with an intense cheese flavour.  We were given slices of baguettes to accompany it and was even offered more after we finished- very generous. Where I ordered the Cassoulet De Toulouse which consisted of  lingot beans served with duck, sausages and pork my boyfriend ordered his most loved Boeuf Bourguignon. My main was lovely, beautiful slow cooked succulent duck and pork belly which went extremely well with the lingot beans. But the flavours could not compare to my boyfriend's Boeuf Bourguignon. Where my dish was cooked in a very light refreshing tomato flavour it was that rich beef stock in red wine in the Boeuf Bourguignon that won me over.The beef in the Boeuf Bourguignon was tender, chunky, mixed with halved potatoes which could have been of a more fluffy variety but still very pleasant. The broth also had a nice sweetness from the carrots. It was a bit runny but there was a lot of depth and really flavourful. If I wasn't so full I would have got some bread to dish up the rest of the sauce. Overall it was a beautiful meal. Sadly the prices does remind you you're in a tourist area as the prices for mains vary from £12.50- £24.95.There is also a 2 course set menu available at £13.50 with the choice of onglet or moules as your main for those who are looking for a fairer price. Even with the high prices, in return you do get a very unique experience, homely french cooking in a old lively French restaurant conveniently located next to Covent Garden. I will definitely be back for sure even if it is to see our host again, Marion who made our day. It would be great to try out the other dishes too and get a chance to visit the seating area downstairs. A great discovery and looking forward to our next visit :).

photos.caption: Photo of Le Garrick - London, United Kingdom. Boeuf Bourguignon
Photo of Le Garrick - London, United Kingdom. Cassoulet De Toulosse (duck, sausages and pork)
Photo of Le Garrick - London, United Kingdom. Complimentary bread

n8f6QyXOmXXp7vVbhLHiiQ.text: Authentic, reasonably-priced, delicious French food. I keep going back and it never disappoints! Even my French friends agree :-)
